note.body: The default value should likely be `G_DESKTOP_WEEKDAY_DEFAULT`, which tells the system (via settings or settings daemon to fallback to locale settings). This is meant more as an override.

Technically, [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) defines weekday numbers as being from 1 through 7, beginning with Monday and ending with Sunday, so officially the "standard" is supposed to be Monday by default, although of course at least [half](https://www.timeanddate.com/calendar/days/first-day-of-the-week.html) of countries don't do that (and even that map is not accurate, because I know for a fact that it's not uniform like that in my country).

Usually the start of the week follows `LC_TIME`:

```
$ env LC_TIME=de_DE.UTF-8 locale first_weekday
2
$ env LC_TIME=en_US.UTF-8 locale first_weekday
1
```

Also should the default value use the American English variant, i.e. `sunday`, like is usually done for translated strings, or should we do the same as was done for the clock format setting in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gsettings-desktop-schemas/-/merge_requests/75?
I don't think so, as it's not referring to an actual date/time (such as how some countries do MM/DD/YYYY and some do DD/MM/YYYY). At least that's what I'm gathering from the gettext documentation.
Should this use `l10n="time"`?

target_title: Setting org.gnome.desktop.datetime automatic-timezone to true seems to have no effect

note.body:
Related issue:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-control-center/-/issues/3100
Rebased on latest `master` to bump the build version so this can still be depended on in latest gnome-control-center. No other changes.
I think the enum should have a value for "default" which would use the locale to determine the first weekday

How do you differentiate though, between Settings changing the default, and the user changing the default? Is there something I'm missing there? Or a system being bootstrapped with a non-English locale, where the user will never change the weekday manually?
Sure, the Evolution can follow the system settings.
No, and the default would be changed in settings to match the locale unless it's overridden.

The whole work around this is really cool! However, I wonder if there should also be a "default locale" option. Right now I personally would appreciate this feature. But I'd bet most users are happy with their current locale's default. Hard-coding Monday as default, will have the consequence of the new default being "wrong" for like half of them? Or am I missing something?

For historical context, this is inspired by how Evolution has been doing it for years:

* https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution/-/blob/master/data/org.gnome.evolution.calendar.gschema.xml.in?ref_type=heads#L427
* https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution/-/blob/master/data/org.gnome.evolution.calendar.gschema.xml.in?ref_type=heads#L11

I'm also hoping that @mcrha will be open to the idea of using this in the future, so that Evolution can inherit this setting from GNOME too (a bit like 12-hour vs 24-hour time format), that way all the apps can benefit.
cc @jfft

note.body: Jamie would like to have a go at this and the related Control Center issue :)
There are no security concerns.

hello, I had a question as an end-user. This question might sound silly, but I was genuinely wondering. 
if someone wants to keep using Cantarell, or any other unmaintained or old font, are there any security related concerns to that (like there are security risks to using outdated apps or software)? Were there any security concerns behind the GNOME team's decision to switch to Inter? Or is it all just about support for newer features that Cantarell couldn't offer?
